chapter.subject: Chemistry
chapter.chapter_name: Study of the First Element — Hydrogen

concepts.concept_name: Position of Hydrogen in Periodic Table - Dual Nature

questions.question_text: Hydrogen is said to have a dual nature in the periodic table because it resembles:

options.label: C
options.text: Both alkali metals (Group IA) and halogens (Group VIIA)

questions.key_concept: Dual nature of hydrogen due to similarities with alkali metals and halogens.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen's placement at the top of the periodic table without disturbing its symmetry was suggested by:
questions.key_concept: Historical placement of hydrogen in the periodic table.

questions.question_text: Which statement is a common MISCONCEPTION about hydrogen's properties?

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrogen has only one valence electron.

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen's properties are identical to those of sodium and chlorine.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen can form both cations and anions.

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen resembles but is not identical to alkali metals or halogens.

questions.question_text: If an element X has one electron in its outermost shell and forms a neutral oxide, which group characteristic is it LEAST likely to share completely?

options.label: A
options.text: The tendency to form a unipositive ion like Group IA.

options.label: B
options.text: The formation of acidic oxides like Group VIIA.

options.label: D
options.text: Existing as diatomic molecules like Group VIIA.

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen's neutral oxide differs from acidic oxides of halogens.

questions.question_text: Compare hydrogen with alkali metals and halogens. Which property is EXCLUSIVE to hydrogen among the three?

options.label: B
options.text: Having only one electron shell (K-shell only).

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen atom has only one shell, unlike alkali metals and halogens which have multiple shells.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen is placed in Group IA but is not a true alkali metal. The primary reason for this distinction is that hydrogen:

options.label: A
options.text: is a gas at room temperature while alkali metals are solids.

options.label: B
options.text: forms a neutral oxide (H2O), while alkali metal oxides are basic.

options.label: C
options.text: has a lower atomic number than lithium.

questions.key_concept: Nature of oxide is a key differentiating property.

concepts.concept_name: Similarities of Hydrogen with Alkali Metals

questions.question_text: Hydrogen is similar to alkali metals because both:

options.label: A
options.text: have seven electrons in their valence shell.

options.label: B
options.text: form anions by gaining an electron.

options.label: C
options.text: have one electron in their valence shell and form positive ions.

questions.key_concept: Similarity in valence electrons and ion formation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a property shared by hydrogen and alkali metals like sodium?

options.label: A
options.text: They act as strong oxidizing agents.

options.label: B
options.text: They burn in oxygen to form their respective oxides.

options.label: C
options.text: Their oxides are acidic in nature.

questions.key_concept: Both hydrogen and alkali metals burn in oxygen.

questions.question_text: A student says, 'Since hydrogen and sodium both have a valency of 1, they will form similar types of compounds with all elements.' What is the flaw in this reasoning?

options.label: A
options.text: Valency alone does not determine chemical behavior; the nature of the element (metal/non-metal) matters.

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium has a valency of 2, not 1.

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen does not form compounds with non-metals.

options.label: D
options.text: Sodium does not burn in oxygen.

questions.key_concept: Valency is one factor; chemical character (electropositive/electronegative) leads to different behaviors.

questions.question_text: In the reaction CuO + H2 -> Cu + H2O, hydrogen acts as a reducing agent. Which alkali metal would show a SIMILAR application?
questions.key_concept: Both hydrogen and alkali metals (like K, Na) act as reducing agents.

questions.question_text: Compare the electropositive character of hydrogen and alkali metals. The correct order of decreasing electropositive character is:
questions.key_concept: Alkali metals are strongly electropositive; hydrogen is less electropositive than them but more than copper.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen and alkali metals both can form cations (H+ and Na+). However, the H+ ion is unique because:

options.label: A
options.text: it has no electrons, while Na+ has 10 electrons.

options.label: B
options.text: it is larger in size than the Na+ ion.

options.label: C
options.text: it is not formed in aqueous solutions.

questions.key_concept: H+ is just a proton with no electrons.

concepts.concept_name: Similarities of Hydrogen with Halogens

questions.question_text: Hydrogen resembles halogens because both:

options.label: C
options.text: exist as diatomic molecules (H2, Cl2, etc.).

questions.key_concept: Diatomic nature is a key similarity with halogens.

questions.question_text: Which electronic configuration feature is shared by hydrogen and halogens?

options.label: A
options.text: They have one electron less than the nearest inert gas configuration.

options.label: B
options.text: They have one electron more than the nearest inert gas configuration.

options.label: C
options.text: They have completely filled valence shells.

options.label: D
options.text: They have two electrons in their valence shell.

questions.key_concept: H (1) needs 1e- to attain He (2) config; Cl (2,8,7) needs 1e- to attain Ar (2,8,8) config.

questions.question_text: A student thinks hydrogen is exactly like a halogen because it can form an anion (H-). Why is this comparison limited?

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrogen forms H- only under specific conditions, while halogens form anions (X-) much more readily and typically.

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrogen cannot form an anion under any condition.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen is a metal, so it cannot form anions.

questions.key_concept: While both can gain an electron, halogens are strongly electronegative and typically form anions, whereas hydrogen primarily shows electropositive character.

questions.question_text: In a combination reaction with a reactive metal like sodium, which pair of elements would show analogous behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrogen and Chlorine (both can form NaCl and NaH)

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrogen and Oxygen (both can form Na2O and NaH)

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen and Helium (both are light gases)

questions.key_concept: Both hydrogen and chlorine (a halogen) combine directly with sodium to form ionic compounds (NaH, NaCl).

questions.question_text: Compare the physical states of hydrogen and halogens at room temperature. Which statement is accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrogen and fluorine are gases, chlorine is a gas, bromine is liquid, iodine is solid.

options.label: B
options.text: All halogens and hydrogen are colorless gases.

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen is a solid, while halogens are all gases.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen is a liquid, while fluorine and chlorine are gases.

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen is a gas; halogens show a gradation in physical states down the group.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen shows some electronegative character like halogens. This is because hydrogen:

options.label: A
options.text: can gain an electron to form a hydride ion (H-), attaining the stable helium configuration.

options.label: B
options.text: always takes electrons from metals more easily than fluorine.

options.label: D
options.text: is a stronger oxidizing agent than chlorine.

questions.key_concept: Electronegative character is shown by the tendency to gain electrons.

concepts.concept_name: Discovery and Occurrence of Hydrogen

questions.question_text: Who is credited with the discovery of hydrogen and established that water is formed when it burns?
questions.key_concept: Henry Cavendish discovered hydrogen and its property of forming water on combustion.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen gets its name from the Greek words meaning:
questions.key_concept: The name 'hydrogen' was given by Lavoisier based on its property of forming water.

questions.question_text: A student reads, 'Hydrogen is abundant in the universe.' They conclude it must also be the most abundant free element in Earth's atmosphere. Why is this conclusion incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrogen is abundant in the universe (e.g., sun, stars) but is present only in traces in Earth's free atmosphere (~0.01%).

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrogen is not abundant anywhere in the universe.

options.label: C
options.text: Hydrogen is the most abundant free element in Earth's atmosphere.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen is only found deep inside the Earth's core.

questions.key_concept: Distinction between cosmic abundance and terrestrial occurrence (free vs. combined).

questions.question_text: Which of the following common substances is the richest source of hydrogen by chemical composition?

options.label: D
options.text: All of these contain hydrogen in combined state.

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen occurs in combined state in water, acids, hydrocarbons, carbohydrates, etc.

questions.question_text: Compare the occurrence of hydrogen in the free state versus the combined state on Earth. The correct statement is:

options.label: A
options.text: Free hydrogen is abundant in the atmosphere, while combined hydrogen is rare.

options.label: B
options.text: Free hydrogen is found in traces, while combined hydrogen is abundant in water, living tissues, and minerals.

options.label: C
options.text: Both free and combined hydrogen are found in equal amounts.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen does not exist in the combined state on Earth.

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen is mainly found in combined form; free hydrogen is minimal.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen is found in combined state in acids. This is because in acids, hydrogen is present as:

options.label: B
options.text: H+ ions (cations) combined with an anion.

questions.key_concept: In acids, hydrogen is present in the combined form as positively charged ions (H+).

concepts.concept_name: Preparation from Water - Reaction with Cold Water

questions.question_text: Which metals react with cold water to produce hydrogen gas?
questions.key_concept: Only very reactive metals (K, Na, Ca) react with cold water.

questions.question_text: When sodium reacts with cold water, the products are:
questions.key_concept: 2Na + 2H2O -> 2NaOH + H2

questions.question_text: A student observes that potassium and sodium both float and dart on water during their reaction. They conclude calcium will also float. Why is this conclusion likely wrong?

options.label: A
options.text: Calcium sinks in water because its density is greater than water, unlike K and Na.

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium is less reactive and does not react with water at all.

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium vaporizes and flies away, so floating is not observed.

options.label: D
options.text: Calcium reacts only with steam, not cold water.

questions.key_concept: Physical behavior (floating/sinking) depends on density, not just reactivity.

questions.question_text: To safely prepare a small amount of hydrogen using sodium, one should use:

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium metal dropped directly into water.

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium amalgam (alloy with mercury) reacted with water.

options.label: C
options.text: Sodium heated strongly in air first.

questions.key_concept: Sodium amalgam reacts smoothly and safely with water to produce hydrogen.

questions.question_text: Compare the reactions of potassium and calcium with cold water. Which observation is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Potassium reacts more violently than calcium and can catch fire; calcium produces a milky solution.

options.label: B
options.text: Calcium reacts more violently than potassium.

options.label: C
options.text: Both produce colorless solutions that turn red litmus blue, but only potassium's solution is milky.

questions.key_concept: Relative reactivity (K > Ca) and nature of product (Ca(OH)2 is sparingly soluble, making solution milky).

questions.question_text: Potassium is stored under kerosene oil. The primary reason for this is to prevent:

options.label: A
options.text: Its reaction with nitrogen in the air.

options.label: B
options.text: Its reaction with oxygen and water vapour present in air, which would cause it to tarnish or catch fire.

options.label: C
options.text: Its evaporation, as it is volatile.

options.label: D
options.text: Its reaction with kerosene, which makes it more stable.

questions.key_concept: Highly reactive alkali metals are stored in inert organic solvents to avoid air and moisture.

concepts.concept_name: Preparation from Water - Reaction with Hot Water/Steam on Metals

questions.question_text: Which metal reacts with boiling water to give hydrogen?
questions.key_concept: Mg reacts with boiling water (hot water).

questions.question_text: When red-hot iron reacts with steam, the products are:
questions.key_concept: 3Fe + 4H2O (steam) -> Fe3O4 + 4H2

questions.question_text: A student heats aluminium with steam and observes that the reaction stops after some time. They think the aluminium is fully used up. What is the more likely reason?

options.label: A
options.text: The formed aluminium oxide (Al2O3) coats the metal, preventing further contact with steam.

options.label: B
options.text: Aluminium does not react with steam at all.

options.label: C
options.text: The hydrogen produced dissolves back into the metal.

questions.key_concept: Protective oxide layer formation halts the reaction for Al, Zn, and Mg.

questions.question_text: If you need to prepare hydrogen continuously using steam and a metal, and you must avoid a reversible reaction, which metal would you NOT choose?
questions.key_concept: The reaction of iron with steam is reversible (3Fe + 4H2O ⇌ Fe3O4 + 4H2), so hydrogen must be removed to continue.

questions.question_text: Compare the reactions of magnesium with boiling water and with steam. The key difference is:

options.label: A
options.text: With boiling water, Mg forms Mg(OH)2; with steam, it forms MgO. Both liberate H2.

options.label: B
options.text: With boiling water, Mg forms MgO; with steam, it forms Mg(OH)2.

options.label: C
options.text: Magnesium reacts only with steam, not with boiling water.

options.label: D
options.text: No hydrogen is produced in either case.

questions.key_concept: Different conditions (hot water vs. steam) lead to different products (hydroxide vs. oxide).

questions.question_text: The reaction between steam and red-hot iron is described as reversible. This means:

options.label: A
options.text: The products can react to re-form the original reactants under the same conditions, leading to an equilibrium.

options.label: B
options.text: The reaction goes to completion and then reverses upon cooling.

options.label: C
options.text: The reaction is very fast in both directions simultaneously.

options.label: D
options.text: The reaction cannot occur in the forward direction.

questions.key_concept: Definition of a reversible reaction and equilibrium.

concepts.concept_name: Activity Series of Metals and its Salient Features

questions.question_text: What is the activity series of metals?

options.label: A
options.text: A list of metals arranged in alphabetical order.

options.label: B
options.text: A list of metals arranged in decreasing order of their reactivity.

options.label: C
options.text: A list of metals arranged by their atomic number.

options.label: D
options.text: A list of metals that do not react with water.

questions.key_concept: Definition of the activity/ reactivity series.

questions.question_text: Which metal is at the top of the activity series?
questions.key_concept: Potassium is the most reactive metal.

questions.question_text: A student sees the activity series: K, Na, Ca, Mg, Al, Zn, Fe... H... Cu. They conclude hydrogen is a metal. What is the actual reason for hydrogen's inclusion?

options.label: A
options.text: Hydrogen is included as a reference point because it can form H+ ions, and metals above it can displace it from acids/water.

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrogen is a metallic element with luster and conductivity.

options.label: C
options.text: All non-metals are included in the activity series.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen is placed there by mistake.

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen is included based on its ability to form positive ions, serving as a benchmark for displacement.

questions.question_text: According to the activity series, which of these reactions is NOT possible?
questions.key_concept: Copper is below hydrogen and does not react with water or dilute acids to give H2.

questions.question_text: Compare the reducing power and electropositive character of metals in the activity series. Which statement is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Both reducing power and electropositive character decrease down the series.

options.label: B
options.text: Reducing power increases but electropositive character decreases down the series.

options.label: C
options.text: Electropositive character increases but reducing power decreases down the series.

options.label: D
options.text: Both remain constant throughout the series.

questions.key_concept: Metals at the top (like K) are strongest reducing agents and most electropositive.

questions.question_text: A metal higher in the activity series can displace a metal lower in the series from its salt solution. The underlying reason for this is:

options.label: A
options.text: The more reactive metal loses electrons more easily, reducing the ions of the less reactive metal to the metallic state.

options.label: B
options.text: The less reactive metal forces the more reactive metal into solution.

options.label: C
options.text: The salt solution acts as an oxidizing agent only for metals at the top.

options.label: D
options.text: An acid is always needed for such displacement.

questions.key_concept: Displacement reactions are redox reactions driven by relative ease of oxidation.

concepts.concept_name: Displacement of Hydrogen from Dilute Acids

questions.question_text: Hydrogen is displaced from dilute acids by metals that are:

options.label: A
options.text: below hydrogen in the activity series.

options.label: B
options.text: above hydrogen in the activity series.

questions.key_concept: Metals more reactive than hydrogen (above H in series) displace it from dilute acids.

questions.question_text: Which acid is commonly NOT used for laboratory preparation of hydrogen from metals?

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above can be used.

questions.key_concept: Dilute nitric acid is an oxidizing agent and usually does not yield H2.

questions.question_text: Lead (Pb) is above hydrogen in the activity series, yet it does not react with dilute HCl or H2SO4 to give hydrogen. This is because:

options.label: A
options.text: The reaction initially forms an insoluble coating (PbCl2 or PbSO4) that stops further reaction.

options.label: B
options.text: Lead is actually below hydrogen in the series.

options.label: C
options.text: Lead needs to be heated strongly to react.

options.label: D
options.text: Dilute acids become concentrated when in contact with lead.

questions.key_concept: Exception due to formation of an insoluble, protective layer.

questions.question_text: In a lab, you need to produce a steady stream of hydrogen using a metal and acid. Which combination is most appropriate?
questions.key_concept: Zinc with dilute acid is the standard lab method; granulated zinc contains impurities that catalyze the reaction.

questions.question_text: Compare the reactions of Mg, Al, Zn, and Fe with dilute HCl. The correct order of decreasing vigor (most vigorous first) is:
questions.key_concept: Vigor of reaction correlates with position in activity series (Mg is above Al, which is above Zn, which is above Fe).

questions.question_text: Dilute nitric acid is generally not used to prepare hydrogen from metals because it is:

options.label: A
options.text: a powerful oxidizing agent that oxidizes the hydrogen produced to water.

options.label: B
options.text: too weak an acid to react with any metal.

options.label: C
options.text: a reducing agent that absorbs hydrogen.

questions.key_concept: Oxidizing nature of HNO3 prevents H2 evolution (except with very dilute HNO3 and Mg/Mn).

concepts.concept_name: Displacement of Hydrogen from Alkalis by Amphoteric Metals

questions.question_text: Which metals are known for their unique nature of reacting with alkalis to produce hydrogen?
questions.key_concept: Zn, Pb, Al are amphoteric and react with hot concentrated alkalis.

questions.question_text: When zinc reacts with hot concentrated sodium hydroxide, the salt formed is:
questions.key_concept: Zn + 2NaOH -> Na2ZnO2 + H2

questions.question_text: A student thinks that since zinc reacts with acids and alkalis, its oxide must be neutral. What is the correct nature of zinc oxide?

options.label: A
options.text: It is amphoteric (reacts with both acids and bases).

questions.key_concept: The unique nature (reacting with acids and alkalis) stems from the amphoteric nature of their oxides/hydroxides.

questions.question_text: If you have a sample containing aluminium and iron filings, which reagent could you use to dissolve only the aluminium and produce hydrogen?
questions.key_concept: Aluminium is amphoteric and reacts with NaOH; iron does not react with alkalis.

questions.question_text: Compare the reactions of zinc with dilute acid and with concentrated alkali. The common product in both reactions is:
questions.key_concept: Both reactions produce H2, but different salts are formed.

questions.question_text: Zinc, lead, and aluminium are called 'unique' in the context of hydrogen preparation because:

options.label: A
options.text: They can displace hydrogen from both acids and hot concentrated alkalis, unlike most metals.

options.label: B
options.text: They are the only metals that react with cold water.

options.label: C
options.text: They are the least reactive metals known.

options.label: D
options.text: They do not react with any acid.

questions.key_concept: Definition of their unique nature based on dual reactivity.

concepts.concept_name: Laboratory Preparation of Hydrogen (Standard Method)

questions.question_text: In the standard laboratory preparation, hydrogen is produced by the action of:

options.label: B
options.text: Granulated zinc on dilute hydrochloric or sulphuric acid

questions.key_concept: Standard lab method reactants.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen gas is collected by the downward displacement of water because it is:

options.label: A
options.text: Heavier than air and soluble in water.

options.label: B
options.text: Lighter than air and insoluble in water.

options.label: C
options.text: Virtually insoluble in water and forms explosive mixture with air.

options.label: D
options.text: Highly soluble in water and supports combustion.

questions.key_concept: Reasons for collection over water.

questions.question_text: A student uses pure zinc instead of granulated zinc for lab preparation. The reaction is slow. Adding a few drops of copper sulphate solution speeds it up. Why?

options.label: A
options.text: Copper ions get reduced to copper metal which deposits on zinc, setting up a galvanic cell and catalyzing the reaction.

options.label: B
options.text: Copper sulphate reacts with acid to produce more hydrogen.

options.label: C
options.text: Copper sulphate makes the zinc purer.

questions.key_concept: Granulated zinc contains impurities like copper that act as catalysts.

questions.question_text: In the lab setup, the thistle funnel's end should be dipped under the acid. This is to:

options.label: A
options.text: Prevent the gas from escaping through the funnel.

options.label: B
options.text: Speed up the reaction by stirring.

options.label: D
options.text: Prevent water from entering the flask.

questions.key_concept: Standard precaution to maintain a closed system.

questions.question_text: Compare the use of concentrated H2SO4 vs. dilute H2SO4 in hydrogen preparation from zinc. Concentrated H2SO4 is not used because it:

options.label: A
options.text: Produces SO2 gas instead of H2.

options.label: B
options.text: Does not react with zinc at all.

options.label: C
options.text: Produces H2S gas as an impurity.

questions.key_concept: Zn + 2H2SO4(conc) -> ZnSO4 + SO2 + 2H2O

questions.question_text: Before collecting hydrogen in a gas jar, a test tube full of the gas is collected and brought to a flame. If it burns quietly, it indicates:

options.label: A
options.text: All air has been expelled from the apparatus, and pure hydrogen is coming out.

options.label: B
options.text: The acid is exhausted and no more gas is produced.

questions.key_concept: Precaution to avoid explosive mixture with air.

concepts.concept_name: Impurities in Lab-prepared Hydrogen and their Removal

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a common impurity in hydrogen prepared from zinc and dilute sulphuric acid?
questions.key_concept: Common impurities: H2S, SO2, oxides of nitrogen, PH3, AsH3, CO2, water vapour.

questions.question_text: To remove hydrogen sulphide impurity, the gas is passed through:
questions.key_concept: Pb(NO3)2 + H2S -> PbS (black precipitate) + 2HNO3

questions.question_text: A student thinks concentrated sulphuric acid is the best drying agent for hydrogen. Why is it not used?

options.label: A
options.text: It reacts with hydrogen to form water and sulphur dioxide, thus consuming the gas.

options.label: B
options.text: It is not hygroscopic and cannot absorb water.

questions.key_concept: H2SO4(conc) + H2 -> 2H2O + SO2

questions.question_text: For obtaining pure dry hydrogen, what is the correct sequence of passing the impure gas through reagents?
questions.key_concept: Logical sequence: remove PH3/AsH3 first, then H2S, then acidic gases, then dry.

questions.question_text: Compare the roles of caustic potash solution and fused calcium chloride in hydrogen purification. Caustic potash primarily removes ____, while calcium chloride removes ____.
questions.key_concept: Specific functions of different purifying and drying agents.

questions.question_text: Arsine (AsH3) and phosphine (PH3) impurities are removed by passing hydrogen through silver nitrate solution because:

options.label: A
options.text: They react with AgNO3 to form non-volatile silver compounds (Ag3As, Ag3P), leaving the gas.

options.label: B
options.text: They dissolve in AgNO3 solution without reacting.

options.label: C
options.text: They reduce AgNO3 to silver metal which catalytically decomposes them.

options.label: D
options.text: They form soluble complexes with silver ions.

questions.key_concept: Chemical reaction involved in removal of PH3 and AsH3.

concepts.concept_name: Manufacture of Hydrogen - Bosch Process

questions.question_text: In the Bosch process, the primary raw materials are:
questions.key_concept: Raw materials for Bosch process.

questions.question_text: In the Bosch process, the catalyst used in the second step (conversion of water gas) is:
questions.key_concept: Catalyst: Fe2O3; Promoter: Cr2O3.

questions.question_text: A student thinks the Bosch process yields pure hydrogen directly after the catalytic step. What important separation step is actually needed?

options.label: A
options.text: Separation of carbon dioxide (and any unreacted carbon monoxide) from the hydrogen mixture.

options.label: B
options.text: Separation of nitrogen from the mixture.

options.label: C
options.text: Separation of steam, as all other gases condense.

options.label: D
options.text: No separation is needed; the product is pure H2.

questions.key_concept: The product after the second step is a mixture of CO2 and H2 (with some CO).

questions.question_text: Carbon monoxide is removed from the hydrogen mixture by passing it through:
questions.key_concept: CuCl + CO + 2H2O -> CuCl.CO.2H2O (complex formation).

questions.question_text: Compare the first and second steps of the Bosch process in terms of heat change. The first step (C + H2O -> CO + H2) is ____, while the second step (CO + H2 + H2O -> CO2 + 2H2) is ____.
questions.key_concept: Thermodynamics of the Bosch process steps.

questions.question_text: In the Bosch process, excess steam is used in the second step (catalytic conversion). The main purpose of this excess steam is to:

options.label: A
options.text: Shift the equilibrium towards the production of more hydrogen and carbon dioxide.

questions.key_concept: Application of Le Chatelier's principle to maximize H2 yield.

concepts.concept_name: Manufacture of Hydrogen - Electrolysis of Water

questions.question_text: In the electrolysis of acidulated water, hydrogen gas is evolved at the:
questions.key_concept: H+ ions move to cathode and get reduced to H2.

questions.question_text: A small amount of sulphuric acid is added to water before electrolysis to:
questions.key_concept: Pure water is a poor conductor; acid provides ions.

questions.question_text: A student sets up electrolysis of pure water (without adding acid) and observes no gas evolution. They conclude water cannot be electrolyzed. What is the actual reason?

options.label: A
options.text: Pure water has very few ions, so it is a poor conductor of electricity, resulting in negligible current.

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrogen and oxygen instantly recombine to form water.

options.label: C
options.text: The electrodes dissolve in pure water.

options.label: D
options.text: Electrolysis requires a base, not an acid.

questions.key_concept: Need for an electrolyte to facilitate electrolysis.

questions.question_text: If during electrolysis of acidulated water, the volume of hydrogen collected at cathode is 20 ml, the volume of oxygen collected at anode would be approximately:
questions.key_concept: 2H2O -> 2H2 + O2, so H2:O2 volume ratio is 2:1.

questions.question_text: Compare the Bosch process and the electrolysis of water for hydrogen manufacture. A key advantage of electrolysis is:

options.label: A
options.text: It produces very pure hydrogen and oxygen simultaneously.

options.label: B
options.text: It is much cheaper and uses low-grade coke.

options.label: C
options.text: It does not require any electricity.

options.label: D
options.text: It produces a mixture of gases that are easy to separate.

questions.key_concept: Advantages and disadvantages of different manufacturing methods.

questions.question_text: During electrolysis, the H+ ions move towards the cathode. This is because:

options.label: A
options.text: H+ ions are positively charged and are attracted to the negatively charged cathode.

options.label: B
options.text: H+ ions are negatively charged and are attracted to the positive anode.

options.label: C
options.text: Water molecules push them towards the cathode.

options.label: D
options.text: They are lighter than OH- ions.

questions.key_concept: Basic principle of electrolysis: opposite charges attract.

concepts.concept_name: Physical Properties of Hydrogen

questions.question_text: Hydrogen is the _____ gas known.
questions.key_concept: Hydrogen is the lightest gas.

questions.question_text: Which property of hydrogen is demonstrated when soap bubbles filled with it rise rapidly in air?
questions.key_concept: Low density (lightness) causes bubbles to rise.

questions.question_text: A student reads that hydrogen is 'slightly soluble' in water. They plan to collect it over water and are concerned all the gas will dissolve. Is this a valid concern?

options.label: A
options.text: No, because its solubility is very low (~20 mL gas per liter of water), so collection over water is practical.

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, because hydrogen is highly soluble like ammonia.

options.label: C
options.text: Yes, because it reacts with water to form an acid.

options.label: D
options.text: No, because it is completely insoluble.

questions.key_concept: Understanding the practical implication of 'slight solubility'.

questions.question_text: Which application of hydrogen directly utilizes its property of being the lightest gas?
questions.key_concept: Application linked to physical property.

questions.question_text: Compare hydrogen and helium for filling balloons. Hydrogen is lighter, but helium is preferred because helium is:

options.label: A
options.text: Non-flammable/ inert, while hydrogen is highly flammable.

options.label: B
options.text: Heavier than air, so balloons sink.

options.label: C
options.text: More soluble in water, making balloons last longer.

questions.key_concept: Safety consideration overrides slight advantage in lift.

questions.question_text: The phenomenon where palladium metal can absorb a very large volume of hydrogen gas at room temperature is called:
questions.key_concept: Definition of occlusion/adsorption of hydrogen by certain metals.

concepts.concept_name: Chemical Properties - Reaction with Non-metals

questions.question_text: Hydrogen burns in oxygen with a _____ flame.
questions.key_concept: Color of hydrogen flame in air/oxygen.

questions.question_text: The product formed when hydrogen burns in chlorine is:
questions.key_concept: H2 + Cl2 -> 2HCl

questions.question_text: A student hears a 'pop' sound when a mixture of hydrogen and air is ignited. They think the pop is due to hydrogen burning quietly. What does the pop actually indicate?

options.label: A
options.text: It indicates a small, explosive combustion of hydrogen mixed with air (oxygen) in the test tube.

options.label: B
options.text: It indicates the formation of water droplets.

options.label: C
options.text: It means hydrogen is impure and contains water vapour.

options.label: D
options.text: It is the sound of pure hydrogen burning silently.

questions.key_concept: The 'pop' test: small explosion due to H2-air mixture. Pure H2 burns quietly.

questions.question_text: In the Haber process, hydrogen reacts with nitrogen under specific conditions. The main product is:
questions.key_concept: N2 + 3H2 ⇌ 2NH3 (Haber Process).

questions.question_text: Compare the reactions of hydrogen with oxygen and with chlorine. A key difference is:

options.label: A
options.text: Reaction with O2 gives water (H2O), a liquid; reaction with Cl2 gives HCl, a gas that dissolves in water to form an acid.

options.label: B
options.text: Both reactions require a catalyst to proceed.

options.label: C
options.text: Reaction with Cl2 is endothermic, while with O2 it is exothermic.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen does not burn in chlorine.

questions.key_concept: Different products and their states.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen and chlorine can react explosively in direct sunlight because:

options.label: A
options.text: Sunlight provides the activation energy for a rapid, chain reaction that releases a large amount of heat.

options.label: B
options.text: Sunlight cools the gases, making them more reactive.

options.label: C
options.text: Sunlight converts chlorine into an inert gas.

options.label: D
options.text: Hydrogen decomposes into atoms in sunlight, which are less reactive.

questions.key_concept: Photochemical reaction leading to explosion.

concepts.concept_name: Chemical Properties - Reaction with Metals and Metallic Oxides

questions.question_text: When hydrogen is passed over heated copper(II) oxide, the observation is:

options.label: A
options.text: Black copper oxide turns reddish-brown, and water droplets form.

options.label: B
options.text: White powder is formed, and a gas with a smell is released.

options.label: D
options.text: Copper oxide melts and turns yellow.

questions.key_concept: Reduction of CuO to Cu.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen reacts with heated sodium metal to form:
questions.key_concept: 2Na + H2 -> 2NaH

questions.question_text: A student tries to reduce aluminium oxide (Al2O3) to aluminium by passing hydrogen over it. The reaction does not occur. This is because:

options.label: A
options.text: Aluminium is a very active metal; its oxide is stable and not reduced by hydrogen.

options.label: B
options.text: Hydrogen is not a reducing agent.

options.label: D
options.text: The temperature was too low; all metal oxides are reduced by H2 at high temps.

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen reduces only oxides of less active metals (below Al in activity series).

questions.question_text: In the extraction of which metal might hydrogen be used as a reducing agent?
questions.key_concept: Application of H2 as a reducing agent for less active metal oxides.

questions.question_text: Compare the reactions of hydrogen with potassium metal and with lead(II) oxide. In both cases, hydrogen acts as a:

options.label: A
options.text: Reducing agent (removes oxygen from PbO) and an oxidizing agent? Wait, with K, H2 gains electrons? Let's think: 2K + H2 -> 2KH. Here H2 gains electrons (each H gains 1e- to become H-), so it is reduced and acts as an oxidizing agent. With PbO, H2 loses electrons (is oxidized to H2O) and acts as a reducing agent. So the roles are opposite.

options.label: B
options.text: In the reaction with K, hydrogen is reduced (acts as oxidizing agent). In the reaction with PbO, hydrogen is oxidized (acts as reducing agent).

questions.key_concept: Hydrogen can act as both an oxidizing agent (with very active metals) and a reducing agent (with metal oxides).

questions.question_text: Hydrogen is called a 'reducing agent' in the context of its reaction with metallic oxides because it:

options.label: A
options.text: Removes oxygen from the metallic oxide, itself getting oxidized to water.

options.label: B
options.text: Adds oxygen to the metal, forming a higher oxide.

options.label: C
options.text: Reduces the temperature of the reaction.

options.label: D
options.text: Increases the mass of the metal oxide.

questions.key_concept: Definition of a reducing agent in terms of oxygen removal.

concepts.concept_name: Uses of Hydrogen

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a use of hydrogen based on its high heat of combustion?

options.label: A
options.text: As a fuel in oxy-hydrogen torch

questions.key_concept: Use as a fuel.

questions.question_text: The process of converting liquid vegetable oils to solid vanaspati ghee using hydrogen is called:
questions.key_concept: Hydrogenation of oils.

questions.question_text: A student thinks hydrogen is ideal for filling weather balloons because it is the lightest gas. In practice, helium is often used. The main reason is that hydrogen:

options.label: A
options.text: Is highly flammable, posing a safety risk.

questions.key_concept: Safety concern overrides advantage in lightness.

questions.question_text: In which industrial process is hydrogen used as a reactant for making ammonia?
questions.key_concept: Specific industrial process.

questions.question_text: Compare the use of hydrogen in an oxy-hydrogen torch and in hydrogenation of oils. The common factor in both uses is that hydrogen:

options.label: A
options.text: Undergoes a chemical reaction (combustion in torch, addition in hydrogenation).

options.label: B
options.text: Is used in its liquid state.

options.label: C
options.text: Acts as a reducing agent in both.

options.label: D
options.text: Is used because of its low density.

questions.key_concept: Different applications based on different chemical properties.

questions.question_text: Hydrogen is used in the extraction of metals like tungsten from their oxides. This is because hydrogen:

options.label: A
options.text: Acts as a reducing agent, removing oxygen from the metal oxide.

options.label: B
options.text: Acts as an oxidizing agent, adding oxygen to the metal.

options.label: C
options.text: Dissolves the oxide to form a complex.

questions.key_concept: Application based on reducing property.

concepts.concept_name: Oxidation (Addition of Oxygen/Removal of Hydrogen)

questions.question_text: In terms of addition and removal of oxygen, oxidation is:
questions.key_concept: Classical definition of oxidation.

questions.question_text: In the reaction 2Mg + O2 -> 2MgO, magnesium is:
questions.key_concept: Mg gains oxygen, so it is oxidized.

questions.question_text: A student sees the reaction H2S + Cl2 -> 2HCl + S. They say hydrogen sulphide is reduced because it loses hydrogen. What is the correct analysis?

options.label: A
options.text: H2S is oxidized (loses hydrogen), and Cl2 is reduced (gains hydrogen).

options.label: B
options.text: H2S is reduced (loses hydrogen), and Cl2 is oxidized (gains hydrogen).

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a redox reaction.

questions.key_concept: Removal of hydrogen is oxidation, not reduction.

questions.question_text: In the reaction CuO + H2 -> Cu + H2O, which substance is oxidized?
questions.key_concept: H2 gains oxygen (or loses hydrogen from its perspective) to form H2O, so it is oxidized.

questions.question_text: Compare oxidation defined as 'addition of oxygen' and as 'loss of electrons'. In the reaction 2Na + Cl2 -> 2NaCl:

options.label: A
options.text: Sodium is oxidized by both definitions (it combines with chlorine, effectively gaining an electronegative element, and loses electrons).

options.label: B
options.text: Sodium is reduced by both definitions.

options.label: C
options.text: Sodium is oxidized by addition of oxygen only.

questions.key_concept: Different definitions leading to the same conclusion.

questions.question_text: In the electronic concept, oxidation is defined as loss of electrons because:

options.label: A
options.text: The substance that loses electrons increases its positive charge (or decreases negative charge), which corresponds to becoming more oxidized.

options.label: B
options.text: Electrons are added to the substance.

options.label: C
options.text: It always involves addition of hydrogen.

questions.key_concept: Rationale behind the electronic definition.

concepts.concept_name: Reduction (Removal of Oxygen/Addition of Hydrogen)

questions.question_text: In terms of addition and removal of oxygen, reduction is:
questions.key_concept: Classical definition of reduction.

questions.question_text: In the reaction CuO + H2 -> Cu + H2O, copper oxide is:
questions.key_concept: CuO loses oxygen, so it is reduced.

questions.question_text: In the reaction Cl2 + H2S -> 2HCl + S, chlorine gains hydrogen. A student concludes chlorine is oxidized. What is the correct term?

options.label: C
options.text: Chlorine is neither oxidized nor reduced.

options.label: D
options.text: Chlorine acts as an oxidizing agent and is itself reduced.

questions.key_concept: Gaining hydrogen is reduction. The oxidizing agent (Cl2) gets reduced.

questions.question_text: Which of the following processes involves reduction?

options.label: B
options.text: Heating of mercuric oxide to give mercury and oxygen

questions.key_concept: 2HgO -> 2Hg + O2; HgO is reduced to Hg (loss of oxygen).

questions.question_text: Compare reduction defined as 'removal of oxygen' and as 'gain of electrons'. In the reaction ZnO + C -> Zn + CO:

options.label: A
options.text: ZnO is reduced by both definitions (loses oxygen and the Zn ion gains electrons).

options.label: B
options.text: ZnO is oxidized by both definitions.

questions.key_concept: Different definitions aligning for the same substance.

questions.question_text: In a redox reaction, if one substance is oxidized, another must be reduced. This is because:

options.label: A
options.text: The electrons lost by the oxidized substance are gained by the reduced substance.

options.label: B
options.text: Oxygen atoms are created and destroyed simultaneously.

options.label: D
options.text: The reaction stops if only one process occurs.

questions.key_concept: Fundamental principle of redox: electron transfer.

concepts.concept_name: Oxidizing and Reducing Agents

questions.question_text: An oxidizing agent is a substance that:
questions.key_concept: Definition: Oxidizing agent is reduced.

questions.question_text: In the reaction CuO + H2 -> Cu + H2O, the oxidizing agent is:
questions.key_concept: CuO is reduced, so it is the oxidizing agent.

questions.question_text: A substance X removes hydrogen from H2S to form S. Student A says X is an oxidizing agent. Student B says X is a reducing agent because it takes hydrogen. Who is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: Student A is correct: removing hydrogen from another substance is oxidation, so X causes oxidation and is itself reduced, making it an oxidizing agent.

options.label: B
options.text: Student B is correct: taking hydrogen means it is reduced, so it is a reducing agent.

options.label: C
options.text: Both are wrong; X is a catalyst.

questions.key_concept: The agent that causes oxidation (H removal) is the oxidizing agent.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a common oxidizing agent?
questions.key_concept: Examples of oxidizing agents.

questions.question_text: Compare hydrogen in the reactions: (i) CuO + H2 -> Cu + H2O and (ii) 2Na + H2 -> 2NaH. In reaction (i), H2 acts as a ____, and in reaction (ii), it acts as an ____.
questions.key_concept: Hydrogen can act as both, depending on the other reactant.

questions.question_text: In a redox reaction, the oxidizing agent is always reduced itself. This is because it:

options.label: A
options.text: Accepts electrons (or oxygen, or adds hydrogen) from the substance being oxidized.

options.label: B
options.text: Donates electrons to the other substance.

questions.key_concept: Mechanism of action of an oxidizing agent.
